Japanese cuisine typically uses kelp (konbu) as nothing more than a flavoring agent; it's used to make dashi which is a base for a LOT of dishes, especially ramen broth. There's a ton of umami present in kelp and that's why a lot of Japanese food has a lot of savory notes to it.

I don't know about other countries, I can only say for mine, but in Russia we eat kelp (Laminaria). Where I am you can find it in almost any food shop pickled in a plastic container (often with vegetable oil, with or without onion, carrot etc., I saw it with shrimp). It's not extremely cheap, but totally affordable, like picked cucumbers. You can get it in big and tiny food shops where you buy salads and cooked food by weight. My aunt knows where to buy raw frozen kelp which can be transformed into similar product. You can get a kelp dish in some cafes. It's not everywhere like bread or milk, but really easy to find. I buy it from time to time and I really like the taste. I actually prefer it to pickled olives; but not to pickled cucumbers.
Today we answer the age old question: Will it Kelp?!
Don't the Japanese use it in soups and salads? My mom used to make mince pork soup with it. They taste great! Yes, I'm Asian.

How about using it to substitute in casseroles and soups? I used some of the sushi nori dried kelp in my crockpot veggie soup instead of kale or spinach for a change of pace. It worked as a good source of leafy greens, but then I did use a bunch of other veggies, so still relying on land-raised food sources, like onions, bell pepper, and lima beans.
